Chapter 22: The Ten Inexhaustible Treasuries
At that time, Bodhisattva Forest of Merit again said to the bodhisattvas:
Buddha's disciples!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have ten kinds of treasuries that the buddhas of the past, present, and future have already taught, will teach, and are currently teaching.
What are the ten?
Namely:

The treasury of faith, the treasury of precepts, the treasury of shame, the treasury of remorse, the treasury of hearing, the treasury of giving, the treasury of wisdom, the treasury of mindfulness, the treasury of upholding, and the treasury of eloquence. These are the ten.
Buddha's disciples!
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's treasury of faith?

This bodhisattva has faith in the emptiness of all dharmas, faith in the signlessness of all dharmas, faith in the wishlessness of all dharmas, faith in the non-action of all dharmas, faith in the non-discrimination of all dharmas, faith in the non-reliance of all dharmas, faith in the immeasurable nature of all dharmas, faith in the unsurpassed nature of all dharmas, faith in the difficulty of surpassing all dharmas, and faith in the non-arising of all dharmas.
If a bodhisattva is able to accord with all dharmas in this way and give rise to pure faith, then when hearing the inconceivable Dharma of the buddhas, his mind will not be timid;
when hearing of the inconceivable nature of all buddhas, his mind will not be timid;
when hearing of the inconceivable nature of the realm of sentient beings, his mind will not be timid;ğŸ”½when hearing of the inconceivable nature of the Dharma realm, his mind will not be timid;
when hearing of the inconceivable nature of the realm of space, his mind will not be timid;
when hearing of the inconceivable nature of the realm of nirvana, his mind will not be timid;
when hearing of the inconceivable nature of the past world, his mind will not be timid;
Hearing of the inconceivable future, their minds are not timid;ğŸ”½Hearing of the inconceivable present, their minds are not timid;
Hearing of the inconceivability of entering all kalpas, their minds are not timid.
Why is this?
This bodhisattva has single-minded, firm faith in the buddhas and knows that the wisdom of the buddhas is boundless and inexhaustible.

In the innumerable worlds of the ten directions, each has innumerable buddhas who have attained, are attaining, and will attain supreme perfect enlightenment, who have appeared in the world, are appearing in the world, and will appear in the world, who have entered nirvana, are entering nirvana, and will enter nirvana. The wisdom of those buddhas does not increase or decrease, is not born or extinguished, does not advance or retreat, is not near or far, is not knowing or abandoning.
This bodhisattva enters the wisdom of the buddhas and accomplishes faith that is boundless and inexhaustible;

Having attained this faith, the mind does not regress, is not mixed up, cannot be destroyed, is unattached, always has a foundation, accords with the sages, abides in the TathÄgata's family, protects and upholds the lineage of all buddhas, increases the faith and understanding of all bodhisattvas, accords with the wholesome roots of all tathÄgatas, and gives rise to the skillful means of all buddhas.
This is called:
the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's treasury of faith.
The bodhisattva, abiding in this treasury of faith, is then able to hear and uphold all the Buddha's teachings and explain them to sentient beings, causing them all to awaken.
Buddha's disciple!
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's treasury of precepts?

This bodhisattva accomplishes the precept of universal benefit, the precept of non-acceptance, the precept of non-abiding, the precept of no regret or resentment, the precept of no conflict or dispute, the precept of no harm or injury, the precept of no defilement or impurity, the precept of no greed or seeking, the precept of no fault or error, and the precept of no violation or transgression.
What is the precept of universal benefit?
This bodhisattva upholds pure precepts, originally for the benefit of all sentient beings.
What is meant by not accepting precepts?
This bodhisattva does not accept any precepts of non-Buddhists, but naturally practices diligently and upholds the equal and pure precepts of the buddhas of the three times.
What is meant by not abiding in precepts?
When this bodhisattva upholds precepts, his mind does not abide in the desire realm, the form realm, or the formless realm.
Why is this?
Because he upholds precepts without seeking rebirth there.
What is meant by precepts without regret?
This bodhisattva always abides in a mind without regret.
Why is this?
Because he does not commit grave offenses, does not engage in flattery, and does not violate pure precepts.
What is meant by precepts without conflict?
This bodhisattva does not violate previous prohibitions, nor does he create new ones;
His mind always accords with the precepts that lead to nirvana, and he fully upholds them without violation.
They do not, due to upholding the precepts, trouble other sentient beings, causing them to suffer, but only wish for all to always be joyful and uphold the precepts.
What is the precept of non-harming?
This bodhisattva, due to the precepts, does not study various spells, create medicines, or harm sentient beings, but only upholds the precepts in order to rescue and protect all sentient beings.
What is the precept of non-mixture?
This bodhisattva does not cling to extreme views, does not uphold mixed precepts, but only observes dependent origination and upholds the precepts of liberation.
What is the precept of non-greed?
This bodhisattva does not manifest strange appearances, proclaiming his own virtues, but only upholds the precepts in order to fulfill the liberating Dharma.
What is the precept of non-fault?
This bodhisattva does not arrogantly say, I uphold the precepts;
seeing those who violate the precepts, he also does not despise or humiliate them,
but only unifies his mind and upholds the precepts.
What is the precept of non-transgression?

This bodhisattva permanently abandons killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, false speech, divisive speech, harsh speech, meaningless speech, greed, ill-will, and wrong views, and fully upholds the ten wholesome actions.
When the bodhisattva upholds these without violating the precepts, he thinks like this:
'All sentient beings violate pure precepts due to delusion;
Only the World-Honored Buddha can know the causes and conditions by which sentient beings give rise to delusion and violate pure precepts.
I should accomplish unsurpassed enlightenment and extensively expound the true Dharma for sentient beings, enabling them to be free from delusion.'
This is called:
The second precept treasury of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Buddha's disciple!
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's treasury of shame?
This bodhisattva recollects the various evils he has done in the past and gives rise to shame.
The bodhisattva thinks like this:

'From beginningless time until now, all sentient beings have been each other's parents, siblings, brothers, and sisters. Due to the afflictions of greed, anger, delusion, pride, flattery, deceit, and all other afflictions, we have harmed each other, oppressed each other, committed adultery, and killed, creating all kinds of evil.

All sentient beings are also like this, creating all kinds of evil due to the afflictions. Therefore, we do not respect each other, do not honor each other, do not follow each other, do not humble ourselves before each other, do not guide each other, do not cherish each other, but kill each other and become enemies.
Reflecting on myself and all sentient beings, in the past, present, and future, we engage in shameful acts, which the Buddhas of the three times know and see.
If I do not now cut off this shameful conduct, the Buddhas of the three times will also see me.
How can I continue to engage in it without stopping?
It is utterly unacceptable.
Therefore, I should single-mindedly eliminate them, realize supreme perfect enlightenment, and extensively expound the true Dharma for sentient beings.'
This is called:
The third treasury of shame of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
Buddha's disciple!
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's treasury of conscience?
This bodhisattva reflects on his past, various greedy pursuits of the five desires without satiation, and how this increased greed, anger, and delusion and all other afflictions:
'I should not engage in these things again.'

He also thinks:ğŸ”½'Sentient beings lack wisdom, give rise to various afflictions, fully engage in evil dharmas, do not respect each other, do not revere each other, and even become enemies with each other.
They commit all these evils, rejoice in doing so, pursue and praise them, blind without the eye of wisdom, and know nothing.'
In a mother's womb, entering the womb to receive birth, forming a defiled body, ultimately reaching white hair and wrinkled face.
The wise one observes that this is merely the impure dharma born from sexual desire, known and seen by the Buddhas of the three times.
If I still engage in this now, I would be deceiving the Buddhas of the three times.
Therefore, I should cultivate shame and quickly accomplish supreme perfect enlightenment, widely speaking the true dharma for sentient beings.'
This is called:
The fourth shame treasure of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Buddha's disciple!
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's hearing treasure?
This bodhisattva knows that because this thing exists, that thing exists; because this thing does not exist, that thing does not exist;
because this thing arises, that thing arises; because this thing ceases, that thing ceases;
these are worldly dharmas, these are supramundane dharmas;
these are conditioned dharmas, these are unconditioned dharmas;
These are wholesome dharmas, these are unwholesome dharmas.
What is meant by 'because this exists, that exists'?
Namely:
Because of ignorance, volitional formations exist.
What is meant by 'because this does not exist, that does not exist'?
Namely:
Because of the non-existence of consciousness, name-and-form does not exist.
What is meant by 'because this arises, that arises'?
Namely:
Because of the arising of craving, suffering arises.
What is meant by 'because this ceases, that ceases'?
Namely:
Because of the cessation of existence, birth ceases.
What are worldly dharmas?
Namely:
Form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness.
What are supramundane dharmas?
Namely:
Precepts, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and vision of liberation.
What are conditioned dharmas?
Namely:
The desire realm, the form realm, the formless realm, and the realm of sentient beings.
What are unconditioned dharmas?
Namely:
Space, nirvana, conditioned cessation, unconditioned cessation, and the nature of dependent origination.
What are the indeterminate dharmas?
They are:

The four noble truths, the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, the four kinds of fearlessness, the four establishments of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of awakening, and the eightfold noble path.
What are the indeterminate dharmas?
They are:
The world has an end, the world has no end, the world both has an end and has no end, the world neither has an end nor has no end;
The world is eternal, the world is not eternal, the world is both eternal and not eternal, the world is neither eternal nor not eternal;

After the TathÄgata's nirvÄá¹‡a, he exists, after the TathÄgata's nirvÄá¹‡a, he does not exist, after the TathÄgata's nirvÄá¹‡a, he both exists and does not exist, after the TathÄgata's nirvÄá¹‡a, he neither exists nor does not exist;

Whether I and sentient beings exist, whether I and sentient beings do not exist, whether I and sentient beings both exist and do not exist, whether I and sentient beings are neither existent nor nonexistent;
How many TathÄgatas have entered parinirvÄá¹‡a in the past?
How many ÅšrÄvakas and Pratyekabuddhas have entered parinirvÄá¹‡a?
How many TathÄgatas will there be in the future?
How many ÅšrÄvakas and Pratyekabuddhas?
How many sentient beings?
How many Buddhas are presently dwelling?
How many ÅšrÄvakas and Pratyekabuddhas?
How many sentient beings?
Which TathÄgata appeared first?
Which ÅšrÄvakas and Pratyekabuddhas?
Which sentient beings?
Which TathÄgata will appear last?
Which ÅšrÄvakas and Pratyekabuddhas?
Which sentient beings?
Which dharma is at the beginning?
Which dharma is at the end?
Where does the world come from and where does it go?
How many worlds are formed?
How many worlds are destroyed?
Where do worlds come from and where do they go?ğŸ”½What is the beginning of birth and death?
What is the end of birth and death?
These are called indeterminate dharmas.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva thinks like this:
'All sentient beings in birth and death lack much learning and cannot understand all these dharmas.
I should arouse the intention to uphold the treasury of much learning, realize supreme perfect enlightenment, and expound the true Dharma for all sentient beings.'
This is called:
The fifth treasury of much learning of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Buddha's disciple!
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's treasury of giving?
This bodhisattva practices ten kinds of giving, namely:

Giving by reducing, giving by exhausting, giving inwardly, giving outwardly, giving inwardly and outwardly, giving everything, giving in the past, giving in the future, giving in the present, and ultimate giving.
Buddha-Son!
What is the giving of sharing and reducing by bodhisattvas?
This bodhisattva is by nature kind and compassionate, and delights in practicing generosity.
If he obtains delicious food, he does not keep it all for himself, but must share it with sentient beings before eating it himself;
He treats all the things he receives in the same way.
When he eats himself, he thinks like this:
'In my body there are 80,000 kinds of worms that depend on me to live. When my body is full and happy, they are also full and happy;
When my body is hungry and suffering, they are also hungry and suffering.
I now accept this food and drink, wishing to make all sentient beings fully satisfied.'
In order to give to them, he eats it himself, not greedy for the taste.
He further thinks like this:
'For a long time in the night, I have been attached to my body, wanting to fill it and satisfy it with food and drink.
Now, I give this food to sentient beings, wishing to forever cut off attachment to my body.'
This is called:
The giving of sharing and reducing.
What is the bodhisattvas' giving of total exhaustion?
Buddha's disciple!

This bodhisattva obtains various superior-tasting food and drink, incense, flowers, clothing, and necessities for life. If he uses them himself, he will be comfortable and live a long life. If he gives them to others, he will be poor, suffer, and die prematurely.
At that time, someone may come and say:
'All that you have, you must give to me.'
The bodhisattva thinks to himself:

'From beginningless time until now, I have lost my body countless times due to hunger and thirst, and have never been able to benefit sentient beings and obtain good benefits even to the extent of a tiny particle.
Now I will also be like in the past and give up my life. Therefore, I should benefit sentient beings and give them everything I have;
even to the end of my life, I will not begrudge anything.'
This is called:
the giving of total exhaustion.
What is the bodhisattvas' giving of the inner?
Buddha's disciple!
This bodhisattva was young, upright, and handsome, his body adorned with fragrant flowers and garments;
he had just received the abhiá¹£eka and the position of a wheel-turning king, possessing the seven treasures, ruling the four continents.
At that time, someone came and said to the king:
'Great king, you should know!
I am now old and decrepit, my body afflicted by grave illness, alone and weak, death will come soon;
if I can obtain the king's hands, feet, blood, flesh, head, eyes, bones, and marrow, my life may be saved.
I only pray that the great king will not hesitate or begrudge anything;
merely see me with compassion and give to me!'
At that time, the bodhisattva thought like this:
'Now this body of mine will surely die in the end, without any benefit;
it is fitting to quickly abandon it to save sentient beings.'
Having thought this, he gave it to them without any regret.
This is called:
inner giving.
What is the bodhisattvas' external giving?
Buddha's disciple!
This bodhisattva, in the prime of youth and beauty, endowed with all the characteristics, adorned with famous flowers and fine garments;
Just having received the abhiá¹£eka, the position of a wheel-turning king, endowed with the seven treasures, ruling the four continents.
At that time, someone came and said to the king:
'I am now poor and destitute, oppressed by various sufferings.
I only wish that you, with your kindness, would take pity on me and give up this kingly position to provide for me;
I shall then rule and enjoy the blessings of the king!'
At that time, the bodhisattva thought like this:
'All glory and prosperity will surely decline and end. At the time of decline and end, it will no longer be able to benefit sentient beings.
I should now follow their requests and fulfill their wishes.'
Having thought this, he immediately gave it to them without any regret.
This is called:
External giving.
What is the bodhisattvas' internal and external giving?
Bodhisattva!
This bodhisattva, as mentioned above, is in the position of a wheel-turning king, possessing the seven treasures and ruling the four continents.
At that time, someone may come and say to him:
This wheel-turning position, the king has occupied for a long time. I have never obtained it.
I only wish that the great king would give it up to me, and also his body, to be my servant!
At that time, the bodhisattva thinks like this:
My body, wealth, treasures, and the king's position are all impermanent and subject to decay.
I am now in my prime, wealthy and powerful over the world;
the beggar is present, I should use the impermanent to seek the permanent Dharma.
Having thought this, he immediately gives it up, even to the point of using his body as a servant, without any regret in his mind.
This is called:
inner and outer giving.
What is meant by the bodhisattva's giving of everything?
Buddha's disciple!
This bodhisattva, as explained above, is in the position of a wheel-turning king, possessing the seven treasures and ruling the four continents.
At that time, there are countless poor people who come before him and say:
Great king, your fame is heard in the ten directions. We have come here because we admire your reputation.
We now each have something to ask for. We hope you will show universal compassion and allow us to fulfill our wishes!
Then, the poor people from that great king ask for various things, such as the country, wife and children, hands and feet, blood and flesh, heart and lungs, head and eyes, marrow and brain.
At that time, the bodhisattva thinks in his mind:ğŸ”½All affection and love will eventually separate, and they do not benefit sentient beings.
I now wish to permanently abandon greed and love, and use all these things that will certainly be scattered to fulfill the wishes of sentient beings.
Having had this thought, they give everything without any regret or aversion towards sentient beings.
This is called:
universal giving.
What is a bodhisattva's past giving?

This bodhisattva hears the merits and virtues of the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the past, and upon hearing it, is not attached, realizes it is not existent, does not give rise to discrimination, is not greedy or indulgent, does not seek to grasp it, and has no reliance;
seeing the Dharma as a dream, without any solidity;
with regard to the roots of goodness, does not give rise to the notion of existence, and also has no reliance;
but in order to teach and transform attached sentient beings and mature the Buddha Dharma, he expounds it;
and moreover observes:
The dharmas of the past, if sought in the ten directions, are utterly unobtainable.
Having had this thought, he ultimately abandons all past dharmas.
This is called:
past giving.
What is a bodhisattva's future giving?

This bodhisattva hears the practices of future buddhas, understands that they do not exist, does not grasp at characteristics, does not delight in being reborn in the lands of buddhas, does not savor or become attached, and also does not become disgusted;
he does not dedicate his roots of goodness to them, nor does he withdraw his roots of goodness from them. He always diligently practices without ever abandoning them;
he only wishes to use those objects to gather in sentient beings, to speak the truth for them, and to enable them to mature the buddha-dharmas;
but these dharmas are neither located nor not located, neither internal nor external, neither near nor far.
He further thinks like this:
'If dharmas do not exist, they cannot be abandoned.'
This is called:
Giving to the future.
What is giving of bodhisattvas in the present?

This bodhisattva hears the devas of the Heaven of the Four Kings, the Heaven of the Thirty-three Celestials, the Heaven of YÄma, the Heaven of Delight, the Heaven of the Masters of Others' Creations, the BrahmÄ Heaven, the Heaven of BrahmÄ's Retinue, the Heaven of BrahmÄ's Ministers, the Heaven of Great BrahmÄ, the Heaven of Limited Radiance, the Heaven of Boundless Radiance, the Heaven of Radiant Splendor, the Heaven of Limited Virtue, the Heaven of Boundless Virtue, the Heaven of Universal Purity, the Heaven of Limited Good, the Heaven of Boundless Good, the Heaven of Ultimate Good, the Heaven of No Affliction, the Heaven of No Heat, the Heaven of Excellent Vision, the Heaven of Excellent Appearance, the Heaven of the Highest Peak, and even hears the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas endowed with merit.
Having heard, his mind is neither confused nor sunken, neither aggregated nor scattered, but only observes that all conditioned things are like a dream and are not real, and has no attachment;
In order to cause sentient beings to abandon the evil destinies, with a mind free from discrimination, to cultivate the bodhisattva path, and to accomplish the Buddha Dharma, he expounds it for them.
This is called:
present giving.
What is a bodhisattva's ultimate giving?
Buddha's disciple!
If there are innumerable sentient beings who lack eyes, ears, nose, tongue, hands, or feet, and they come to the bodhisattva and say:
'Our bodies are unfortunate and our faculties are incomplete.
We only hope that you, with kind compassion, will use skillful means to give away what you have and enable us to be complete.'
When the bodhisattva hears this, he immediately gives it to them;
even if it takes asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas for their faculties to be complete, he does not give rise to a single thought of regret or stinginess.
He only observes his own body, from first entering the womb, the impure subtle form, the various faculties of the body, birth, old age, sickness, and death;

Furthermore, contemplating this body, there is no true reality, no sense of shame or dishonor, it is not the possession of sages, it is foul-smelling, unclean, the bones and joints hold it together, it is smeared with blood and flesh, the nine orifices constantly flow, and people despise it.
Having contemplated in this way, not a single thought of attachment arises.
Furthermore, he thinks like this:
'This body is fragile and brittle, without any solidity.
How can I now give rise to attachment?
I should give it to them to fulfill their wishes.
As I do this, I will lead all sentient beings to not give rise to craving and attachment to body and mind, and to fully accomplish the pure wisdom body.'
This is called:
The ultimate giving.
This is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's sixth treasury of giving.
Buddha's disciple!
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's treasury of wisdom?
This bodhisattva truly knows form, truly knows the accumulation of form, truly knows the cessation of form, and truly knows the path to the cessation of form;

Truly knows feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, truly knows the accumulation of feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, truly knows the cessation of feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, and truly knows the path to the cessation of feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness;
Truly knows ignorance, truly knows the accumulation of ignorance, truly knows the cessation of ignorance, and truly knows the path to the cessation of ignorance;
Truly knows craving, truly knows the accumulation of craving, truly knows the cessation of craving, and truly knows the path to the cessation of craving;
Truly knows the Å›rÄvaka, truly knows the Å›rÄvaka's teachings, truly knows the accumulation of the Å›rÄvaka, and truly knows the nirvÄá¹‡a of the Å›rÄvaka;
Truly knows the pratyekabuddha, truly knows the pratyekabuddha's teachings, truly knows the accumulation of the pratyekabuddha, and truly knows the nirvÄá¹‡a of the pratyekabuddha;

They know the bodhisattvas as they truly are, they know the bodhisattva teachings as they truly are, they know the accumulation of bodhisattvas as it truly is, and they know the nirvÄá¹‡a of bodhisattvas as it truly is.
How do they know?

They know that it is created by the causes and conditions of the karmic retribution of various practices, all of which are false and empty, without reality, not self, not solid, and not established with even the slightest dharma.
They wish to cause sentient beings to know its true nature and extensively proclaim it for them.
What do they proclaim?
They proclaim that all dharmas are indestructible.
What dharmas are indestructible?

Form is indestructible, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are indestructible, ignorance is indestructible, the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas are indestructible.
Why is it so?
All dharmas are without action, without an agent, without speech, without location, unborn, unarisen, not given, not taken, without movement or change, and without function.
Bodhisattvas accomplish such immeasurable wisdom treasuries. With little effort, they understand all dharmas, naturally illuminating and penetrating, not relying on others for realization.
This inexhaustible treasury of wisdom has ten kinds of inexhaustibility, therefore it is called inexhaustible.
What are the ten?
Namely:

Because skillful means of extensive learning are inexhaustible, because good spiritual friends are inexhaustible, because well-discriminating sentence meanings are inexhaustible, because entering the profound Dharma realm is inexhaustible, because adorning with the wisdom of a single flavor is inexhaustible, because accumulating all merits and virtues without wearying the mind is inexhaustible, because entering all dhÄraá¹‡Ä« gateways is inexhaustible, because being able to discriminate all sentient beings' languages and sounds is inexhaustible, because being able to eliminate all sentient beings' doubts is inexhaustible, and because manifesting all buddhas' spiritual powers to teach and transform all sentient beings, causing their practices to continue without interruption, is inexhaustible;
These are the ten.
This is called the seventh wisdom treasury of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
Those who abide in this treasury attain inexhaustible wisdom and are able to universally enlighten all sentient beings.
Buddha's disciple!
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's treasury of mindfulness?

This bodhisattva abandons delusion and attains complete mindfulness. He recollects past lives, one life, two lives, up to ten lives, a hundred lives, a thousand lives, a hundred thousand lives, countless hundreds of thousands of lives, eons of formation, eons of destruction, eons of formation and destruction, not just one eon of formation, not just one eon of destruction, not just one eon of formation and destruction, a hundred eons, a thousand eons, a hundred thousand koá¹­is of nayutas, up to countless, immeasurable, boundless, incomparable, incalculable, inexpressible eons;
he recollects the name of one buddha, up to the names of inexpressibly inexpressible buddhas;
They contemplate the prediction of Buddha's appearance in the world, up to the prediction of the appearance of innumerable Buddhas in the world;
They contemplate the sutras spoken by a Buddha, up to the sutras spoken by innumerable Buddhas;
As with sutras, so too with geya, vyakarana, gatha, nidana, udana, itivrttaka, jataka, vaipulya, adbhutadharma, avadana, and upadeÅ›a;
They contemplate a single assembly, up to innumerable assemblies;
They contemplate expounding a single Dharma, up to expounding innumerable Dharmas;ğŸ”½They contemplate the various natures of a single faculty, up to the various natures of innumerable faculties;
They contemplate the innumerable various natures of a single faculty, up to the innumerable various natures of innumerable faculties;
They contemplate the various natures of a single afflictive dharma up to the various natures of innumerable afflictive dharmas;
They contemplate the various natures of a single samÄdhi up to the various natures of innumerable samÄdhis.
This contemplation has ten aspects, namely:

Tranquil contemplation, pure contemplation, untainted contemplation, penetrating contemplation, dust-free contemplation, free from various defilements contemplation, taint-free contemplation, radiant contemplation, delightful contemplation, unobstructed contemplation.

When the bodhisattva abides in this contemplation, the entire world cannot disturb or agitate him, no heterodox theories can move him, his past wholesome roots are all purified, he is unstained by worldly dharmas, he cannot be destroyed by demons and non-Buddhists, and he does not forget his past lives in subsequent rebirths;
He expounds the Dharma without end in the past, present, and future;
In all worlds, he dwells with sentient beings without fault;
Entering the assemblies of all buddhas without obstruction, able to approach all buddhas.
This is called:
The eighth recollection treasury of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
